content.question: A large, horizontal, uniform disk is rotating freely with angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> about a vertical axis at its center, as shown in the figures. A smaller uniform disk, which is less massive than the large disk, is initially at rest and centered directly above the large disk. At time <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> the small disk is dropped down onto the large disk, and at a later time <math alttext="t sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> the two disks are rotating together at the same angular speed <math alttext="omega sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math>, which is less than <math alttext="omega sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Why is <math alttext="omega sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> less than <math alttext="omega sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> ?

choices.label: Because the total angular momentum of the two-disk system is the same at <math alttext="t sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.
Because the rotational inertia of the small disk is less than that of the large disk.

Because the total kinetic energy of the two-disk system is the same at <math alttext="t sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.

Because the gravitational potential energy of the disks-Earth system is lower at <math alttext="t sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></mstyle></math> than at <math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.
